answers.answer: My son did lose interest in eating from a bottle, but it was when he started teething and eating solid foods.  From about 5 months old we were struggling to get him to eat from a bottle.  He just liked his solid foods better and still does.  He's 13 mo. old now and we too struggled to get just 20 oz of liquid in him per day.  He's just not a big drinker.But your baby is too young to be teething, and I'm assuming you're not giving her solid foods yet.Has she been pooping and peeing the normal amounts?This would concern me also and it's good you didn't ignore it.  I think you definitely need to call her pediatrician and inform him of this.  (I cannot stress highly enough how important it is to have a pediatrician versus a regular family doctor!!).  This should definitely be brought to his attention.  He will check for reasons she won't eat (sore throat, etc) and go from there.

I would definitely contact your pediatrician asap as there could be a multitude of reasons your baby's not that enthusiastic about eating- most of them I'm sure not serious. Could be that she's congested, has a sore throat, gas, etc. Best to check it out now and it's very good that you're aware of the situation. My dd only lost interest in nursing; as the other poster said, when she was teething and onto solids.

Thank you both for your suggestions.  I will call the doctor again today.  I did call last week and since the overall volume of feeding had not really decreased, they were not too concerned.  I think I'll push for bringing her in for a weight check as well.  It seems improtant to me as well that she is not excited about her feedings anymore.  I read somewhere that when a baby tops 12 lbs it's time for rice cereal...is this true?  I won't add it without an OK from her Dr.Thanks again.

I cannot remember the exact weight (15 lbs sticks in my head), but they should be BOTH 4 months or older AND 15 lbs or above.Again, not sure if that's the exact poundage, but that's the gist of it.  Your baby is too young for solids.

Thanks for responding!  We did take Anna to the Dr. today.  Of course, today she seems back to normal and is eager for food.  Strange timing on her part, but we're just happy she feels better. The Dr. noticed that her throat looked a little red, so that fact combined with the early morning snotty nose led her to diagnose that Anna caught "something", but appears to be getting over it.  She asked us to come back in 2 weeks for another weight check and throat exam.  Her weight gain from last month's appt to this one was very good, thank goodness.I know what you mean about not taking your preemie ANYWHERE.  Anna showed up June 20, with a due date of Sept 6.  She came home Aug 15th, and we didn't take her anywhere until late Sept.  It worked very well for us to hole up in the house and let her get adjusted to everything.  I can't imagine how she caught anything now, since neither my husband or I have anything, and we are basically shut-ins since she showed up.  Hope this is all it is.Everything has been so crazy since she was born.  I had a placental abruption in Blockbuster Video, for God's sake.  (Never going there again) I am just now getting to where I don't constantly worry that she's going to stop breathing.  It's never happened since she's been home, but I do worry about everything little thing.We just need to get through this RSV season and we'll both feel better about our babies.  We did not opt for the RSV vaccine.  We talked it over with our pedi who also has 30 week preemie twins, and she felt that our risk factors were such that we did not have to do it.  I hope she is right about this.  It had alot to do with Anna being born in June and her not going into day care.I agree, it is nice to talk to another preemie mom.  Hope to talk to you again, and good luck to you and your family.-Julie in TexasPS- Anna was diagnosed with mild Torticollis, which is basically a stiff neck/shortened muscle from looking to the right all the time.  If you notice your baby always leaning/looking in one direction, start trying to encourage looking in the other direction.  She is going to have to go to physical therapy for this.

My baby is too a preemie born 9/22/05 at 8 weeks early.  He is up to 7lb 9oz and he goes for his bottle like he hasn't ate in a week and I have been worrying that he must not be getting enough.  He takes 3oz a feeding every 3 hrs.  We add a calorie supplement and ground rice cereal to thicken which also add extra calories to my breast milk.  It is good to hear from another preemie mom.  Maybe they are just going through a phase but I think that we just worry so much more with a preemies.  Anyways with my other children which were all term babies they would go through phases and still do.  It seems like they have hollow legs just before a growth sprout then for weeks they wouldn't be interested at all.I would call the ped Dr and do for every little thing.  Preemies are so suspectable to things.  I warned her that I would probably drive her crazy in this next year.  She said that is what she is there for.Do you have the RSV shots done for your baby?  We are for Joshua but still are told not to take him anywhere in public and she told me not to go anywhere for Thanksgiving and not to have anyone over.  That we don't want to introduce any "new" germs to him.Good Luck to you and your family as I know it is hard to be a mother of a preemie.
PS  I am glad your daughter is well.

Joshua came home on a monitor.  Boy am I happy!  He still sets it off while feeding or soon afterwards.  He has reflux which he takes meds for.  Then while he is sleeping which is the scariest and the hardest to bring him out of. He has had only a few episodes of stop breathing but many where his heart rates slows which I don't quite understand How can they be breathing and there heart rate slows?  It still freaks me out he'll turn this dusty gray and sometimes get blusih around his mouth.  While we in the hospital they said that they wanted him to go without an episode for 5 days before he come home.  My response was why is 5 days the magical number?  What says that they wont have an episode on the sixth day.The RSV shots are very expensive, $1500.00  here in In. and they are given once a month.  We have 2 kids in school and a 3 yo at home and my husband had just quit smoking the day Joshua was born.  They figure in the relapse possibility, but to his credit he hasn't had a cig since.I had severe preeclampsia and then developed pulmonary edema.  I was on a vent longer than Joshua so I didn't have to see tha on him.  It was 5 days later before I got to see him and he was on just a nasal canon.  One of the NICU nursed brought him to me and held him on my chest but I was still out and have no reculation of it which makes me sick because I can remember my sister being there.They warned me in the NICU that he may have trouble with his neck.  He does like to hold his head just to the right and I have been trying to encourage him to hold it the other way.  His legs are still so stiff.  It amazes me how hard his legs feel at times but I was told that this is also something that preemies do.

Hi, we are new at this, that is posting, and new at having a newborn around, Emmie was born 3 1/2 weeks early, and she was also born addicted, she is my neices daughter, the state got involved, and my wife and I were the only option she had, except for State Foster, and we couldn't even think of that as an option, Emmie has two problems, the first being born preemie, and she also has a herniaten navel, her original Dr. said she was fine, no hernia, we were not satisfied, so we took her to the womens,& childrens hospital in Charleston Wv. The attending Ped. informed us that it was herniated,but said nothing could be done for it at this time, only to keep a close watch on it? we are worried sick, and could sure use some comments on the herniated navel, other wise she is doing great, she is 3 months old now, and weighs almost 10 lbs,she weighed 4.5 lbs at birth. thanks for this opportunity, and we will appreciate any suggestions. Howiee

question: Hello all.  I have a baby girl born at 29 weeks who is now 2 and a half months old (corrected age).  We have been so lucky with her...no big problems ever the entire time she was in the NICU.  She just had to get bigger and stronger so she could come home.  Now she's about twelve and a half pounds, happy and healthy.All of a sudden she is just not eager to eat.  She used to shark-lunge at her bottle and would WAAAHHH when it wasn't ready fast enough.  Now she never cries for food (even after an 8 hour sleep overnight).  When I give it to her, she gums it around for awhile, then kind of seems like she's going "Oh OK, I guess I'll eat if it's so important to you".  We are still getting about 20 ounces a day into her, but just through persistence since she would be fine stopping after just a few ounces.What's going on?  Any of your babies just suddenly lose interest in eating?  She's not crying or seeming like she's in pain while eating, unless I really keep trying to get her to finish.  No excessive spitting up.  She was eating 6 ounces at 1 or 2 feedings a week ago.  Now she never tops 4.5 ozs.  Any ideas?  I'm so worried about her...she's been doing so well.  (Grossness alert)She does have one big green booger in her nose each morning, but her nose is never runny and it's only in the morning.  Can this be related?  I appreciate any help or suggestions.
title: Losing interest in eating...Worried!!
